Award.AwardTitle: Optically Tweezered Localized Plasmonic Structured Illumination Microscopy (OT-LPSIM) for Ultrafast Super Resolution Bio-imaging

Division.LongName: Div Of Chem, Bioeng, Env, & Transp Sys

Award.AbstractNarration:
Liu 1604216
ABSTRACT

The research will develop a unique optical instrument for super resolution imaging at ultra-fast speed. The instrument will be the first optical imaging tool that has unprecedented resolution in both space (~50nm scale) and time (~20ms scale) simultaneously. It will have a profound impact to the fields of physical science, biomedical imaging and to fields where both high resolution and high speed optical imaging are required.

An innovative combination of plasmonics, structured illumination microscopy, and optical tweezers, will allow a host of fundamental studies on the nanoscale interactions and real-time dynamics of living cells that are impossible to conduct by any other presently available instrument. Localized plasmonic structured illumination (LPSIM) is a structured illumination microscopy (SIM) technique and the plasmonic antenna array provides deep sub-wavelength illumination patterns, leading to much higher resolution in a final reconstructed image.
.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Traditional optical microscopy has its resolution limited by the wave nature of light. Within last two decades, people have witnessed the development of various super-resolution microscopy (SRM) techniques go beyond the Abbe limit and reveal the nanoscale world optically. Single-molecule-localization microscopy, such like PALM and STORM has achieved resolution beyond 10nm, but the imaging speed is typically at minutes scale. STED is possible to address both high-resolution and high-speed but its field of view is quite small due to its point-by-point scanning mechanism. In addition, the high optical power needed also introduce unavoidable photo damage to life specimens. SIM is a wide-field high-speed technology, but its resolution only has about two-fold improvement compared to the diffraction limit. In general, modern adaptions of SRMs not only require high spatial resolution, but also need to address the growing demands of imaging speed, low photo toxicity, simplicity of usage, system cost, and etc. Many derivatives or combinations of those techniques keep on evolving, but there is no single solution to satisfy all the demands at the same time. 

 

As a result of this program, we developed a new SRM technology by the combination of SIM and plasmonics. The new technology is termed as localized plasmonic structured illumination microscopy (LPSIM). We have shown that the LPSIM can simultaneously achieve 50nm spatial resolution and real-time video speed, which represent a unique capability that is extremely challenging to be achieved by other technologies. We also explored the potentials to further improve the resolution by reducing the period of the optical antennas of the LPSIM substrate, or replacing the plasmonic substrate by a designed metamaterial. If information gaps appear in the Fourier space, an iterative image reconstruction method has to be employed to reduce the artifacts in the reconstructed images. The LPSIM and its derivatives represents a very comparative SRM option for applications requiring both resolution and speed. Besides the proof-of-concept demonstration, various experiments were also conducted toward the application of this technique in biological studies. The biocompatibility of the protected LPSIM substrate has been proved excellent and can be used multiple times. 

 

This research program provided comprehensive trainings for two Ph. D students and 1 postdoc researcher in the field of optical instrumentation and optical microscopy. They gained extensive experiences in optical system design, alignment and image reconstruction, and collaboration with biologists. This project resulted the publication of multiple papers on peer-reviewed research journals and several oral presentations at international conferences.
